intro: Niphobolus heteractis, commonly known as the white-flowered bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, white or pale blue flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are tubular at the base and flared at the mouth, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Niphobolus heteractis is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to high-altitude environments.
